fields.summary: Console icons are not showing up when it is built from source on CentOS

fields.description: The gear icon for the options on the landing pages do not show up. See the attachment.
fields.summary: The menu gear icon doesn't show up on the landing pages

comments.body: [~kyolee] Try emptying your cache.  Also, could you provide your browser/platform info?  We switched the gear icons to use an SVG image as a CSS background, which is only supported by relatively recent browsers (see http://caniuse.com/svg-css)

I'm using the up-tot-date Chrome,  Version 33.0.1750.146, on Mac OS X, 10.6.8, and still seeing the issue; my dev. browser has the cache disabled.

And, also noticed that the dashboard's icons for the landing pages have disappeared as well. See the attachment.
The same issues are also seen on Firefox 27.0.1, which is the latest.
[~kyolee] Are you seeing this on latest develop branch?

When checked git log, the latest commit at:

commit 9b62e4c973a6d70b876616a3c989ce27f6b5ad9f
Author: Kamal Gill <kamal@kamalgill.net>
Date:   Fri Mar 7 11:23:24 2014 -0800
[~kyolee] ok, wanted to confirm since I'm not seeing the issue in latest Safari, Chrome, Firefox on my Mac.  I'm running OS 10.8 though, not sure that matters.
That's strange. I am using a different laptop, Mac Air, and also seeing the same issue as well, which also runs OS X 10.6.8.
Going to convert the SVGs to PNGs to fix this.
On second thought, the SVGs render much better than the PNGs and handle responsive layouts much better, so would prefer to keep the SVGs if possible.
Tested with latest Firefox, Chrome, and Opera on Ubuntu (Saucy), where the dashboard SVGs and the landing page gear icons displaying just fine.
Tested with IE 11 on a Surface 2, and the SVG icons appear just fine.

Try to access:

10.111.5.62:8888

as ui-test-acct-00/user00/mypassword1

, which is running on Centos 6.5

The SVG icons will not display if the content type isn't properly set to "image/svg+xml".

Here's the response header for an SVG on the 10.111.5.62 (CentOS) box...
Content-Type: application/octet-stream; charset=UTF-8

And here's the one on my local machine...
Content-Type: image/svg+xml; charset=UTF-8

No clue why the CentOS box would be setting the wrong content type header, as the "Server" response header for both cases is the following...
Server: gunicorn/18.0
[~kyolee] May I assign this to you to troubleshoot on the CentOS box?

[~kgill] just sent out the summary on the installation steps on Centos 6.5. Will revisit the issues once all the dependencies issues get resolved since it'd be better to work on the system with the final, complete packages. but, yes, I will look into the issue soon.
[~kyolee] Understood.  Maybe work with [~Rocky] to have Pyramid set the proper headers for SVG images.  Should be fairly simple via a Pyramid tween, right [~Rocky]?
Yeah sounds simple enough.

I need access to the centos box to test but after having written the tween it occurred to me that this is probably a web server and/or OS specific configuration issue.  What are we running in front of eucalyptus?
[~Rocky]: gunicorn is the WSGI server we're using for production, with nginx as the preferred reverse proxy running on port 80.  AFAICT, the CentOS setup is using gunicorn without nginx.

So here's the situation... python's mimetypes package (which pyramid uses) looks for various mime type files (ie /etc/mime.types) on a *nix based OS.  If no such files can be found, it uses a default set of mime types that does not include one for svg.  On Ubuntu, /etc/mime.types does exist and properly declares svg.  On CentOS, there is no /etc/mime.types or equivalent.

So... are we in a position to provide our own /etc/mime.types file or will I need to figure out something more creative?
So as per discussion I've added a check on eucaconsole startup - if no mime type exists for svg, we add it ourselves.  https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/tree/GUI-497
Approved pull request at https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/375
Not resolved on CentOS production environment, per [~viglesias].
Sorry I got confused by this issue over the weekend - saw it got closed out and assumed someone else had either fixed it or shown that it wasn't really a bug.  I'll jump on this again.
[~Rocky] If setting the proper header rather than adding to the mime types list fixes this issue, let's go with the header approach, esp. since QA is blocked by this ticket.
I found that the problem was that the .svg files weren't being picked up by the "setup.py install" process. I've added *.svg to the MANIFEST.in file. The other fix should be un-necessary.
Problem on a minimal CentOS install is likely due to a missing /etc/mime.types file, which is fixed by requiring mailcap.  Packages have already added the requirement, so closing this ticket.
